posts.name: Ryan Elchahal
posts.cooked:
Hi all,

I hope all of you have had a great month to kick off the season! Recently we’ve been having issues with our front left swerve module. For some reason, this front left module, despite having zeroed it, changes the physical angle it considers “0 degrees” whenever we redeploy robot code, press our syncAzimuth button (a button which syncs the external and internal swerve encoders to counteract slight discrepancies), or, sometimes, when we drive for an extended period of time (more than a few minutes). Strangely, this front left module always goes to a 45/225 degree physical angle when this problem occurs, and when reading out encoder values right after the module moves, we only see a printed value of 0.

We are very confused as this only occurs with one of our swerve modules, not all. We have also taken the module apart by hand to check its mechanics. However, the assembly looks correct, and the encoder does not appear to be slipping.

Any insight would be very much appreciated! Thanks!
Is your magnet glued in well?

posts.name: Josh Buker
posts.cooked: I second checking this. Had the same issue last year when setting up swerve for the first time.

posts.name: Ryan Elchahal
posts.cooked: Did your module also shift to the same new angle every time the problem occurred? Because of this consistency, I was cautious to pin it as a glue issue

posts.name: Richard Budop
posts.cooked: We had a similar issue this year with our modules reading zero when they were off. Even after setting offsets. The issue was because we were subtracting the offset when setting the angle in the beginning and also setting the cancoder’s magnetic offset setting. We removed the magnetic offset and it worked. Don’t know if this is your issue, it just sounded similar.
We also had this issue, worth a check!

posts.name: Ryan Elchahal
posts.cooked: Interesting, I’m definitely going to check this out. Thanks so much! How can you remove the cancoder’s magnetic offset setting? Is there external software?

posts.name: Richard Budop
posts.cooked: You can remove it in the settings in Pheonix tuner, but more than likely it is being set in code. Check your config settings in code for the cancoder. It may be calling a function that sets the magnetic offset.

posts.name: Evan Jordan
posts.cooked: My team was also having this issue. If you are using CANCoders, ensure the correct ID’s are assigned to the correct module in the phoenix tuner. We went through and made sure everything matched up and that fixed our issue.

Hi,

I’m working with @Relch06 . We use MA3 absolute analog encoders.

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked: We have the same issue.  It’s always our front right module and for us, it happen all the time, it happens 1/10 redeployments of code.

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: Wait, I just had a quick question, how are the CANCoder IDs determined?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
somerandomuser:

We use MA3 absolute analog encoders

Thanks for this critical piece of information. Everyone was making assumptions that lead down the wrong path. There is plenty to go wrong if this encoder fails but it’s not the same as a CANcoder.

Check the encoder to verify it works by hand turning and shaking violently without failing.

What model of this encoder are you using? One model works at a snail’s pace (100 rpm) and another can go screaming fast (15000 rpm). (Even the slow one has decent acceleration capability so I doubt that’s your problem - more likely you can over-speed it.)

This encoder is completely self-contained with no adjustment to the magnet possible or needed. The position of the encoder relative to your shaft is determined by how you connected the encoder shaft to the drive shaft. What coupler are you using? is it slipping? Is it aligning well or flexibly so there isn’t excessive side load on the encoder shaft?

Verifying that the analog input port or PWM input port is working correctly is useful.

posts.name: Evan Jordan
posts.cooked: You set them in the Phoenix tuner just like any other CAN device. Just make sure your ID’s are matching with the physical robot by making the lights on them blink so you know which is which. Caused our team quite a few headaches before we found out this was our issue.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
